DOC.HEAD: U.S. Embassy Calls Expulsions `Drastic And Unjustified'
Eds: LEADS thruout to UPDATE with more Nicaraguan comment, background. No pickup.
With AM-Panama, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A U.S. official on Saturday called the expulsion of 20 U.S. diplomats from Nicaragua ``drastic and unjustified'' retaliation for a search by U.S. troops of the Nicaraguan ambassador's home in Panama. On Friday night, President Daniel Ortega gave the diplomats 72 hours to leave. He also ordered the mission to reduce its administrative staff from 320 to 100. Most of those employees are Nicaraguan nationals. ``We were at grave risk of a political-military clash with the United States, which has maintained an aggressive attitude against Latin American countries,'' Ortega said. The action came after U.S. troops invaded the Nicaraguan ambassador's house in Panama City despite his protests. A senior U.S. official in Panama City called the search a mistake and said troops did not know they were in a diplomatic residence. The Nicaraguan Foreign Ministry said 15 U.S. diplomats would be allowed to remain in the country, the minimum prescribed by the Vienna Convention. ``The measure of the Sandinista government is drastic and unjustified,'' said Louis Falino, a spokesman for the U.S. Embassy in Managua who spoke to The Associated Press by telephone. Falino was on the list of those expelled. President Bush said in Houston on Saturday that an apology had been made. ``It's a screw-up and they (U.S. military officials in Panama) have expressed their regrets that it happened,'' Bush said. He added that ``it shouldn't have happened and that's been explained to the Nicaraguans.'' U.S. officials said soldiers were acting on a tip that a large cache of weapons was stored at the home. Soldiers returned the weapons after realizing it was the Nicaraguan diplomat's residence, the State Department said. The search of Ambassador Antenor Ferrey's residence in Panama City was ``outrageous...insolent'' and ``violated principles of international law,'' Ortega said. ``They acted arrogantly, like Rambos!'' Ortega said. He claimed the U.S. soldiers stole more than $2,000 and took some clothes from the residence. U.S. reaction to the charge was not immediately available. Tension between the two countries increased after the Dec. 20 U.S. invasion of Panama and the overthrow of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega. If it does not ease, it could give Ortega an excuse to cancel presidential elections set for Feb. 25. ``We have never discarded the possibility'' of a U.S. invasion of Nicaragua,'' said Manuel Rodriguez, political adviser at the Nicaraguan Embassy in Panama. He spoke before the search, looking down on U.S. troops manning barricades of wire and sandbags at the embassy and checking identification on a side street. ``It's just that the results would not be the same as in Panama. It would cost them a lot more.'' Nicaragua's Soviet-equipped military is the largest force in Central America. The United States has not had an ambassador in Managua since July 1988, when the leftist Sandinista government expelled Ambassador Richard Melton and seven other American diplomats to protest alleged American interference in an opposition rally in Nicaragua. The United States responded by expelling Nicaraguan Ambassador Carlos Tunnerman. U.S. soldiers circled the Nicaraguan Embassy in Panama last week in case Noriega sought refuge there. Nicaragua's Foreign Ministry then ordered the U.S. Embassy in Managua surrounded.
